p: Aboveground biomass declined 60% in response to drought treatments, while warming (W) and W + D only had a minor effect on agb biomass ( Fig. 4, Table 2). Similarly, bgb biomass only responded to drought ( Fig. 4; Table 2), with a 55–66% decline in root biomass in drought and W + D treatments relative to ambient conditions. Total biomass responded to warming ( F 1,7 = 5.87, P = 0.046) and drought ( F 1,7 = 20.57, P = 0.003) but not to the interaction of the two ( F 1,7 = 2.34, P = 0.170; Table 1). Overall, total biomass declined by 55–75% in drought and W + D treatments relative to ambient conditions ( Fig. 4; Table 2). Plant age helped to explain total biomass responses ( Table 1). Marginal r 2 (variance explained by fixed effects) and conditional r 2 values (variance explained by fixed and random effects) were similar for the final total biomass model, suggesting treatments and plant age explained nearly all of the variation in biomass measurements. However, random effects did provide some additional explanatory power (2%; Table 1), with a majority of it being attributed to error ( σ 2 = 0.97; Table 3).
